reviews.review: ... Swift's full-on pop crossover moment remains a career high-point
... shows she never goes out of style.
The vault tracks here might be her best batch yet

name: THE TORTURED POETS DEPARTMENT: THE ANTHOLOGY

reviews.review: The Tortured Poets Department combines the intimacy of Folklore and Evermore with the synth-pop gloss of Midnights to create music that’s wildly ambitious and gloriously chaotic
The whole album is a terrific reminder of the intense, personal connection Swift can conjure in song.
... that matured, time-honed voice coming out of Swift in her latest re-recording is a mirror image of a fan base who came out the other end with her
Even without the country twang, Swift embodies her younger self fully
She channels the original's LP exuberance, does a little revising, and brings along some pop-punk pals
Red is her most interesting full-length to date, but it probably won't be when all is said and done in her career.
I like the feisty ones, as I generally do. But 'Begin Again' and especially 'Stay Stay Stay' stay happy and hit just as hard.
The subtle melodies of Midnights take time to sink their claws in. But Swift’s feline vocal stealth and assured lyrical control ensures she keeps your attention
With its confident songwriting and understated synth-pop, Swift’s sophisticated 10th album indicates that she no longer feels she has to compete with her peers
Her tenth album returns to the dazzling synth-pop of records like '1989' and 'Reputation,' with lyrics caught between a love story and a revenge plot
1989 isn’t a “crossover” success. It’s the album every subsequent blockbuster must now reckon with.
Swift’s songwriting is as consistently razor-sharp as it’s ever been.
With 1989, she expertly sets up the next chapter of what is now even more likely to be a very long career.
